title: I keep getting threating call from collection company about taken me to court on payday wifes cell now too
question: Was involved in big rig accident 12/16/15 have not worked sence this has been going on for that long thinking of filing bankruptcy can I write loan off in bankruptcy to end this
answers: Generally speaking you can discharge accident claims, however, there are some exceptions. Bankruptcy can end those harassing calls, and more importantly release you from personal liability on unsecured debt obligations. I recommend you speak with a bankruptcy attorney as soon as possible.

I agree with the responses from my colleagues and add the following: If you were driving impaired at the time of your big rig accident in 2015, certain debts surrounding the accident my not be dischargeable. More details are needed to give you the best advice. Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer". Some offer a free consultation to sort this out with you. Good luck. Don't forget to give feedback on the Avvo site.

I'm a little unclear about the type of "loan" you are talking about. You used the word "payday" in your question. If it is a payday loan, or pretty much any other type of loan for that matter, it will be discharged when you complete your BK ... along with all of your other dischargeable debt.

You should be able to write off the debt based on the information provided. Most bankruptcy attorneys offer free initial consultations. Click on the AVVO "Find a Lawyer" tab to find several near you. The will tell you if bankruptcy is the right course for you.

Most likely Yes you can discharge the debt. After you file the collections call will stop because there is an automatic stay in place. Speak to a local attorney about all your debts and assets to see if bankruptcy is the right choice....many offer free consultations. Good Luck!

Yes. A bankruptcy will discharge all unsecured debt, with some very specific exceptions. Once a case is filed, all collection activities will stop, including the phone calls.
Seek the advice of local bankruptcy counsel.
